items.title: Is Canada’s hockey culture broken?
items.summary_auto: Questioning hockey culture in Canada can be controversial, but it’s something award-winning author and sports journalist Rick Westhead doesn’t shy away from. In conversation with The National’s Ian Hanomansing, he lays out what he uncovered for his new book We Breed Lions and the impact he hopes it has on the sport.

items.title: Montreal Victoire defeats Toronto Sceptres 3-1, land second straight win
items.summary_auto: Ann-Renée Desbiens made 21 saves, including 11 in the third period, as the Montreal Victoire defeated the Toronto Sceptres 3-1 in Professional Women's Hockey League action Sunday afternoon at Place Bell in Laval, Que.

items.title: Thousands of Santas dash through Liverpool streets for charity
items.summary_auto: Liverpool's annual Santa Dash made spirits bright on Sunday as thousands of runners dressed as Santa Claus took to the streets of the English city for the five-kilometre festive fun run. Participants are encouraged to raise money for local charities as part of the event, which began in 2004.

items.title: Fatal blaze in Fort William First Nation is 4th trailer fire in Thunder Bay, Ont., district in a week
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s Office of the Fire Marshal is investigating a fatal blaze in Fort William First Nation, which marks the fourth trailer fire in the Thunder Bay district within a week. Here's what we know about the recent incidents.

items.title: Trump's new security strategy aligns with Russia's interests, Kremlin says
items.summary_auto: The Kremlin on Sunday welcomed U.S. President Donald Trump's new national security strategy and said it largely accorded with Russia's own perceptions, the first time that Moscow has so fulsomely praised such a document from its former Cold War foe.

items.title: Canada's Summer McIntosh swims to butterfly win and sets U.S. Open record
items.summary_auto: Summer McIntosh capped swimming’s U.S. Open with the event record in the women’s 200-metre butterfly on Saturday in Austin, Texas.

items.title: Liberals at risk in Quebec, appeasing Alberta with ‘solution that failed before’: Guilbeault
items.summary_auto: Chief political correspondent Rosemary Barton speaks with Quebec Liberal MP Steven Guilbeault, who resigned from Prime Minister Mark Carney's cabinet last week, about his party’s deal with Alberta for a potential pipeline to the west coast of B.C., and why he thinks the federal government is stoking Quebec separatism by walking back its climate commitments.

items.title: Fire at a popular nightclub in India’s Goa state kills 25
items.summary_auto: A fire ripped through a popular nightclub in India’s Goa state, killing 25 people, including tourists, the state’s chief minister said Sunday.

items.title: Air Transat to gradually shut down operations over 3 days after union issues strike notice
items.summary_auto: In a statement issued shortly after the mandate was announced by the union, Air Transat called the strike notice "premature." The airline said there has been progress in negotiations and that it's made "generous" contract offers.

items.title: Why was 'incredible' giant cedar cut down, despite B.C.'s big-tree protection law?
items.summary_auto: Conservationists are questioning why an old-growth yellow cedar tree with a diameter that should have ensured its protection and a buffer area around it under provincial law was logged.

items.title: Capacity limits at Edmonton children's hospital lead to chemotherapy delays
items.summary_auto: Samantha Dornbusch has been bringing her son Jaxson to the hospital for the past six years to treat the aggressive blood cancer he’s battling. Over the last two years, on multiple occasions they say they would show up to the hospital only to have staff tell them his treatments would be delayed because there were no beds currently available.

items.title: Israel's Netanyahu says he will meet Trump, second phase of Gaza plan 'close'
items.summary_auto: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday that he will meet U.S. President Donald Trump later this month, saying a second phase of Trump's Gaza plan was close.

items.title: Benin’s interior minister says a coup announced earlier has been foiled
items.summary_auto: There has been no official news about President Patrice Talon since gunshots were heard around the presidential residence. However, the signal to the state television and public radio which was cut off has now been restored.

items.title: Filming disputes at airports and nicotine pouches illegally sold across Canada: CBC's Marketplace cheat sheet
items.summary_auto: CBC's Marketplace rounds up the consumer and health news you need from the week.

items.title: Calgary transit fares going up to $4 — more than riders pay in Toronto, Winnipeg and Vancouver
items.summary_auto: Come January, transit riders in Calgary will have to shell out $4 for a single-ride ticket, a fare that remains higher than other major cities, including Edmonton, Winnipeg, Vancouver and Toronto.

items.title: Alberta lawyers must take Indigenous education course tied to TRC. New legislation could change that
items.summary_auto: A little more than five years ago, the regulator for Alberta's lawyers announced that moving forward, all active Alberta lawyers would be required to take a mandatory Indigenous education course. But new Alberta legislation could change that.

items.title: Winnipeg moves to scrap bird-friendly window bylaw developers argue is barrier to development
items.summary_auto: Conservation groups are raising concerns as the City of Winnipeg considers changing a development bylaw designed to help save birds from fatal window strikes.

items.title: Saint John to pilot using private security to tackle crime
items.summary_auto: Saint John is launching a two-year, $780,000-per-year security pilot in crime-affected areas starting in early February. Guards will focus on de-escalation, not arrests, with oversight from the city.

items.title: Saint John to pilot using private security to tackle crime concerns
items.summary_auto: Saint John is launching a two-year, $780,000-per-year security pilot in crime-affected areas starting in early February. Guards will focus on de-escalation, not arrests, with oversight from the city.

items.title: Paranormal investigator explores ghost ships in latest Hellboy comic set in Labrador
items.summary_auto: Comic book writer Rob Williams says the new Hellboy comic book story, The Ghost Ships of Labrador, was inspired by a MUN folklore student.

items.title: ‘I don’t know who I can trust,’ says Quebec YouTuber harassed by Chinese government
items.summary_auto: Yao Zhang knew something was up when she started seeing fake sexually explicit images of her circulating online. The YouTuber, who often criticizes the Chinese government, is one of several Canadians targeted by a 'spamouflage' campaign led by the People's Republic of China.

items.title: Want to see a snowy owl? This could be your winter
items.summary_auto: This could be an unusually good year to spot snowy owls in southern Canada. Here's why, and how to see these Arctic visitors without disturbing them.

items.title: American F-35s could be serviced in Quebec starting in 2028-29, says L3Harris
items.summary_auto: Companies involved in the F-35 program are actively lobbying the governments of Canada and Quebec to promote potential economic benefits for the country, including a maintenance facility in Mirabel, Que., that could service both Canadian and American fighter fleets.

items.title: In the shadow of a famed Mexico City stadium, a battle for water targets the World Cup
items.summary_auto: Across from Mexico City’s famed Azteca Stadium sits a well that’s at the centre of an ongoing conflict over water rights now threatening to engulf the World Cup’s third visit to the country.
